body_html:
So I've seen SparseTensors used to represent different kinds of data. Such as:

  1. The "typical" meaning of sparse, where each example has a few columns out of many that are present and rest are assumed zero or "". If the sparse_tensor.values are only ever 0 or 1, I consider this a small value space and possibly large feature space.
  2. A convenient way to represent a variable length list of values. e.g. a few strings per example. While maybe this can be made to look like 1), I would consider this to have a small index space (a "few" strings) and a large value space (any possible string).

Good luck with the two-forest, I'd be interested to hear how it goes.

body:
So I've seen SparseTensors used to represent different kinds of data.  Such as:
1. The "typical" meaning of sparse, where each example has a few columns out of many that are present and rest are assumed zero or "".  If the sparse_tensor.values are only ever 0 or 1, I consider this a small value space and possibly large feature space.
2. A convenient way to represent a variable length list of values.  e.g. a few strings per example.  While maybe this can be made to look like 1), I would consider this to have a small index space (a "few" strings) and a large value space (any possible string).  

Good luck with the two-forest, I'd be interested to hear how it goes.
